entry.title: RC - day 24
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • remote check-in (I was late)
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • writing my first app in Swift thanks to Jesse’s workshop
  • pairing with Aissam on WebRTC
  • worked on presentation
  • went to Drunk TED Talks

Living in the Uptown New York has some ups and downs, sadly mostly downs - I was late for my check-in, as going back to the apartment yesterday took me twice as long as usual. I should probably not use the subway after 11pm and lower my expectations. I’ll just think about it as a suburban train rather than what we consider a subway in Europe.

Jesse was kind enough to do another round of his Swift workshop and I’ve built my first iOS app - a simple implementation of Lights Out. It was a fun afternoon activity.

I’ve randomly started talking to Aissam about his current work on WebRTC - a technology that allows streaming video and audio through a simple implementation in the browser. We paired on a Snapchat-like feature I hope he’ll present some time soon.

In the evening we went for Drunk TED Talks on conspiracies. With something advertised as “TED talks” I expected it to be a bit different - the presentations weren’t TED-like, but some presenters did look drunk. There were four conspiracy areas:

  • Nicolas Cage
  • One Direction
  • Blood Cults
  • Jill Stein (Green Party candidate for the US president)

I never thought I’d say that, but the most interesting presentation was on One Direction. There was also a Polish accent I didn’t expect - apparently there is an XVIII-century painting by Karol de Prevot in Sandomierz’s cathedral, allegedly depicting ritual murder of Christians by Jews.

Afterwards we went for drinks to a very nice pub. I’ve tried some seaweed cider, but opted for a regular apple one - the salty taste and seaweed smell weren’t really appealing.

click an image to see the gallery

entry.title: RC - day 23
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Python
  • pairing with Juan on Jekyll plugin
  • added subpages for every date and improved calendar
  • worked on presentation
  • started writing a GitBook on Jekyll
  • slowly getting addicted to podcasts

This week I’ve switched to working mostly with Jekyll, as the blog and website turned out to be a pretty interesting side project. I’ve started writing a GitBook on Jekyll (or more accurately - I wrote a Readme draft), as a byproduct of my learning efforts, as it may be useful to others.

I’ve had a chance to pair with Juan and understand better how Jekyll plugins work. Together we’ve created a plugin for generating a subpage for every category and date. I then implemented them in my calendar - now you can click on any date that has posts and be redirected to an appropriate subpage.

I also worked on my presentation, as 5 minutes needs far more work than a half-hour format, which I’m generally used to. I’m keeping it fun and simple, hopefully it will be interesting enough.

Podcasts are great, I’m listening to them whenever I’m not working. The thread on Zulip grew pretty fast and now I have far more recommendations than I could hope to check in the next month, but that just makes it a challenge, doesn’t it? So far I’ve only listened to all You are not so smart episodes on logical fallacies and some Partially Examined Life, but the list is slowly growing.

entry.title: RC - day 22
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • chat with Adam on frontend design and workflow
  • redesigned my main website

Most of the day I’ve been redesigning my main website to match the blog. I’ve rewritten and simplified the CSS, done some heavy-lifting with reorganising language versions and created a simple logo out of my initials.

I had a nice chat with Adam, who pointed out some things I should work on and the general flow of frontend design. It was pretty helpful, as I disregarded the problems that can arise with a “simple” blog design and maintenance (especially the maintenance). My presentation is growing and mutating, I’m not sure how will it look on Thursday.

As I was feeling unproductive, we went for a short walk with Juliano to get a coffee. Starbucks in Poland may be very different or “Chile Mocha” is something that just doesn’t taste right, either way - don’t drink it. We’ve had a chance to observe some cute and enormous squirrels. Yes, I am going to use squirrel photos to obscure my lower than desired productivity.

click an image to see the gallery

entry.title: RC - day 21
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • went to Central Park
  • learned some exception handling in Ruby
  • reorganized for the next quarter of my batch
  • set-up podcasts for the week

After a long night comes a short day.

I didn’t do much today in terms of working towards my goals, as I was too unfocused to be productive. After walking through Central Park, I mostly worked on getting better organized and reflecting on the first quarter of my batch. All in all it went pretty well, but I want to be more focused and have more tangible products while working towards my goals.

I programmed a bit in Ruby today and learned a lot about exception handling, though I’m not entirely sure I know enough to feel confident using it. I also set-up a long-awaited podcast habit and hope to strengthen it over the next few weeks.

entry.title: Central Park trip
entry.content:
I finally went to Central Park. Starting at the very top at 110th St and exiting nearly two hours later around the 59th St, it was a calming and wonderful experience. During the walk I completely forgot I’m in a vast and restless city.

It reminded me partially of London parks, especially the enormous size of Regent’s Park, but it was far less orderly and thus more interesting. It looks like a preserved part of a once wild environment, which is strange considering how much planning went into creating it.

As I grew accustomed to in NYC, people were dancing, singing, playing and laughing loudly, there was hardly any quiet space by the time I got to the Alice in Wonderland Statue (I couldn’t get a photo without a horde of children climbing on it). Here you can get lost completely, but never away from people.

click an image to see the gallery
entry.summary: I finally went to Central Park. Starting at the very top at 110th St and exiting nearly two hours later around the 59th St, it was a calming and wonderful experience. During the walk I completely forgot I’m in a vast and restless city.

entry.title: RC - day 20
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • drafted presentation for Thursday
  • used Juliano as a rubber duck
  • went for Korean BBQ with Cihan, Joe and Juliano
  • reading some “Gödel, Escher, Bach”

It was a long night. We went for Korean BBQ, planning to come back and do some more programming, but from BBQ we went for some more soju (Korean alcohol) and ended up at a Korean karaoke. It was loads of fun and next week we’ll probably try some Polish cuisine, as Joe was pretty tired of being the guide.

I’ve decided to give a presentation on Thursday on a completely different topic than I initially planned. Instead of pushing my audio analyses and possibly failing to meet the deadline, I want to talk about the blog. From a side, lightweight project it turned into a learning opportunity I didn’t expect.

Juliano was a pretty good rubber duck for Jekyll.

click an image to see the gallery

The post is late because of our BBQ adventures.

entry.title: ElixirConf 2016 - guest post by Juliano
entry.content:
Hi, if you’re reading this (especially Alicja’s Polish translation), then you certainly don’t know me yet. Let me introduce myself.

I’m Juliano, Alicja’s batch-mate from Brazil!

Now that that’s out of the way, let me tell you about Elixir and ElixirConf 2016.

Elixir is an up and coming programming language made by another Brazilian. It leverages a lot of ancient technology (Erlang) and is built in a modern, attractive and well thought out way, making awesome stuff accessible to a broader range of programmers. The community is pretty awesome. People are genuinely friendly and patient and they make an effort to make things accessible to everyone at every level.

ElixirConf 2016 was set in the Disney Swan and Dolphin Resert. It was raining hard and natives from Orlando were talking about “hurricane season”, which I thought was more exciting than Disney itself.

Ever since I arrived to NY I’ve been waiting for a flu to catch me. The weather was very hot, the subway stations were even hotter, and the trains were freezing cold. To me, the NY subway system is like a massive human pasteurization machine, where they successively bake and freeze you between train stops and connections, until all of your bacteria are dead. The cold arrived right on time for ElixirConf and I spent my first conference day with a fever, sore throat and an artificially deep voice. Even so, it was awesome and well worth it.

ElixirConf has doubled in size compared to last year. I was there too during ElixirConf 2015, and actually got a free copy of “Seven More Programming Languages in Seven Weeks” as a “Longest Distance Travelled” Award. We were some 200 programmers flying in from a lot of different places to meet other people excited about this cool new language with an uncertain future. Very few of us were actually using Elixir in our day jobs. Things have changed a bit. This year we were 542 and around 30% of attendees say they run Elixir in their day jobs!

We are a heavy flock of newbies coming into a technology stack that has been there since the 80’s, so there is eventually some friction. Some old-time Erlang developers are not happy with that, which became fuel for jokes in some presentations.

This year, many of the talks were from companies actively using Elixir, talking about their success stories and things they learned. I personally like that kind of presentations a lot.

Conferences are, in the end, much more than just the talks. I’ve met some very nice people from Brazil who were also attending and had a chance to talk at length with some of Elixir’s creators and core contributors. Meeting again with people I’ve seen last year gave the conference sort of a feeling of family, and knowing that many of them, like me, are still not using Elixir at work made me feel that Jessica Kerr’s tear-inducing keynote from last year (here) still echoed in everyone’s hearts.

I’ve also been high-fived by a Michigan fan and approached by two Detroit residents during the conference because I bought a Michigan hoodie at the Detroit airport so I wouldn’t freeze to death during my 10 hour connection.

The closing keynote was done by Boyd Multerer, former engineering leader for Microsoft’s Xbox console for the last 14 years. He gave a very thought provoking presentation and spoke at length about why he chose Elixir and Erlang as his career investment for the next 10 years. It was a very rewarding talk to watch, hearing Boyd come up with compelling reasons why, for him, the Erlang VM and Elixir are the best fit for technology in the next decade, giving confirmation to the intellectual, emotional and financial investment we all had in the language.

I left early, still feeling a little bit feverish, but very much inspired to go back to the RC and write more Elixir.

entry.summary: Hi, if you’re reading this (especially Alicja’s Polish translation), then you certainly don’t know me yet. Let me introduce myself.

entry.title: RC - day 19
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • self check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Ruby
  • algorithms (Stanford course) check-in
  • adding a MVP of a calendar to the blog
  • starting a course on CS in Python
  • trying Halo Top ice cream (and eating only half of them)
  • getting a gig as a cat sitter

Fri-yay has come. The day when sleeping in after a busy week is acceptable. The day when going on a long walk just to get protein ice cream is reasonable.

I’ve managed to barely keep my streaks in order today, meditating on the subway while being very late and doing a warm-up right before the algorithms group meeting.

On top of my algorithms course I still have to catch up with the rest of the group, I’ve started a new CS course in Python (because I want to learn the language and ‘proper’ programming better) and I’m getting ready for the course on audio analysis (because I want to implement some of it in my language-learning app). It does seem like much, but structured courses and peer pressure help with motivation, so I’m going to try managing all three of them over the next few weeks.

I wanted to create a simple and fast github-like calendar for my blog, which turned out to be surprisingly difficult, as I’ve managed to forget all of my JS over the past few months. I got to a Minimum Viable Product after a few hours of relearning the language. I’m planning to introduce more web development back into my routine, I don’t want it to get rusty.

As for the cat sitter gig, I got the dibs on spending a weekend with these two sweet fluffs in two weeks, which will be a great opportunity to have a completely distraction free few days (minus the belly rubs), focusing on my learning.

entry.title: RC - day 18
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Python
  • adding RSS feed to the blog
  • watching presentations
  • doing my first live coding
  • creating a dragon, hairpin, magnets and earrings
  • reading some “Gödel, Escher, Bach”
  • taking part in Abstract Salad Factory

Thursday is a bonding day, with the alumni in the space, presentations and events in the evening.

Abstract Salad Factory was just the beginning of it - a group of people brought various ingredients for salads and then we mixed, matched and stuffed ourselves.

My top three community presentations were:

  • Totes Random - an app generating random numbers from tweets by John, Sean and Taylor
  • an expense tracker with some nifty visuals by Leeor and Taylor
  • a presentation on analogies by Naomi

I also took part in Jade’s intro to 3D printing, by doing my first live coding ever. It was stressful, but great, which means I should do it again.

The Arts and Crafts night was full of fun. There was knitting, drawing, sewing, origami, face painting, hairpin glueing, magnet making, eating and laughing. Some Recurses worked in the midst of it all - I admire their ability to focus, wish mine was that good.
